term_definitions.items: Additional contextual detail to be applied to all compositions.

The period of care to which this composition belongs. This equates to the CONTSYS concept and repesents an admisitrative or contractual spell of care, involving a specific instiution or care provider.
The identifier of the departmental period of care to which this Composition belongs.
Portlet ID from which stores the information where was the composition saved.
The temperature was measured at the buccal mucosa.
The temperature was measured at the sub-lingual mucosa.
Evidence of chills / rigor or shivering.
A measurement of the body temperature, which is a surrogate for the whole body temperature of the person.
A measurement of the body temperature, which is a surrogate for the whole body temperature of the person.
The measured body temperature (as a surrogate for the whole body)
The anatomical site of measurement of the temperature
The anatomical site of measurement of the temperature.
Temperature is measured within the mouth
Temperature is measured from within the external auditory canal
Temperature is measured from the skin of the axilla with the arm positioned down by the side
Temperature is measured within the nasopharynx
Temperature is measured in the urinary bladder
Temperature is measured within the vascular system
The thermal situation of the person who is having the temperature taken
The person is covered by a lesser amount of clothing or bedding than deemed appropriate for the environmental circumstances
The person is covered by an amount of clothing or bedding deemed appropriate for the environmental circumstances
The person is covered by an increased amount of clothing or bedding than deemed appropriate for the environmental circumstances
Description of the conditions applied to the subject that might influence their measured body temperature.
Temperature is measured from exposed skin
Temperature is measured within the vagina
Temperatue is measured within the oesophagus
Temperature is measured in the inguinal skin crease between the leg and abdominal wall
Details about the environmental conditions at the time of temperature measurement
Details about the exertion of the person at the time of temperature measurement
Details about the menstrual cycle of a woman
Details about the device use to measure body temperature
Missed beats of greater than 2 per minute
The number of missed beats per minute
The body site where the pulse was measured
Difference between the rate at the heart apex and a peripheral pulse.
Shape of the pulse wave on palpation
The apex beat of the heart (left 5th intercostal space, mid-clavicular line)
The carotid artery in the neck
Missed beats less than 2 per minute
The characteristics of the heart rate and rhythm.
The mechanical heart rate - usually measured by palpation
The mechanical heart rate - usually measured by palpation. Added terms for ZN requirements.
The rate of the heart in beats per minute.
The observed rhythm of the heartbeat.
Heart rhythm is irregular in a chaotic manner.
Comment about the heart rate and rhythm.
The position of the patient when the heartbeat was recorded.
Person reclining at 45 degrees with legs raised.
The heart rate is present (implied true if rate >0).
The heart rate is present (implied true if rate >0).
Details about the device used to measure heart rate and rhythm.
Details about the method or machine used to record the heart rate and rhythm.
Details about physical exertion being undertaken at the time of recording heart rate and/or rhythm.
Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the heart rate and rhythm measurement. For example, level of anxiety; pain or fever etc.
Source of heart rate and rhythm record.
Derived from the electrical activity of the heart, commonly via an electrocardiograph.
Is the blood pressure reading suitable to be displayed on a graph?
A non-invasive method was used to record blood pressure.
Locations of invasive measurement of blood pressure.
The left ear of the subject.

The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial. pressure in the systemic circulation. Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.

The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial. pressure in the systemic circulation. Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm. 'Unsuitable for graphing' added for local Marand ZN use.
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.
The position of the subject at the time of measurement.
Perloff D, Grim C, Flack J, Frohlich ED, Hill M, McDonald M, Morgenstern BZ. Human blood pressure determination by sphygmomanometry. Circulation 1993;88;2460-2470.
The size of the cuff used for blood pressure measurement.
Common body sites where blood pressure is recorded.
Common body sites where blood pressure is recorded.
A cuff used for an adult thigh - bladder approx 20cm x 42cm.
A cuff for adults with larger arms - bladder approx 16cm x 38cm.
A cuff that is standard for an adult - bladder approx 13cm x 30cm.
The right arm of the person.
The left arm of the person.
The right thigh of the person.
The left thigh of the person.
Standing at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Sitting (for example on bed or chair) at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Reclining at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Lying flat at the time of blood pressure measurement.
The craniocaudal tilt of the surface on which the person is lying at the time of measurement.
The average arterial pressure that occurs over the entire course of the heart contraction and relaxation cycle.
The difference between the systolic and diastolic pressure.
A cuff used for a small adult - bladder approx 10cm x 24cm.
A cuff that is appropriate for a child or adult with a thin arm - bladder approx 8cm x 21cm.
Record which Korotkoff sound is used for determining diastolic pressure using auscultative method.
The fourth Korotkoff sound is identified as an abrupt muffling of sounds.
The fifth Korotkoff sound is identified by absence of sounds as the cuff pressure drops below the diastolic blood pressure.
Lying flat with some lateral tilt, usually angled towards the left side. Commonly required in the last trimester of pregnancy to relieve aortocaval compression.
A cuff used for infants - bladder approx 5cm x 15cm.
A cuff used for a neonate, assuming cuff is the appropriate size for maturity and birthweight of the neonate.
The right wrist of the subject.
The left wrist of the subject.
Details about sphygmomanometer or other device used to measure the blood pressure.
The right ankle of the subject.
Details about physical activity undertaken at the time of blood pressure.measurement.
The left ankle of the subject.
A finger of the subject. Identification of the finger can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.

Body location where blood pressure is measured. Use 'Location of measurement' to select from common sites. Use 'Specific location' to record more specific details or a site that is not in the common set or to refer to an external terminology.
Specific details about the body site where blood pressure is recorded.
Method of measurement of blood pressure.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a stethoscope and Korotkoff sounds.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using palpation (usually of the brachial or radial arteries).
Formula used to calculate the MAP (if recorded in data).
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a blood pressure machine.
Method of measuring blood pressure internally ie involving penetration of the skin and measuring inside blood vessels.
Estimate of the average blood pressure over a 24 hour period.
Sleep status - supports interpretation of 24 hour ambulatory blood pressure records.
Subject is in the natural state of bodily rest.
A toe of the subject. Identification of the toe can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.

Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the blood pressure measurement. For example, level of anxiety or 'white coat syndrome'; pain or fever; changes in atmospheric pressure etc.
Invasive measurement via transducer access line within an artery. Location of the transducer can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.
The observed characteristics of spontaneous breathing as would commonly be recorded as part of a 'vital signs' examination.
Specific abnormal respiratory pattern. Other patterns may be entered as free text or terminology subset defined at specialisation or template level.
Deep chest breathing with or without a visible gasp.
Periods of hyperventilation alternating with periods of apnoea.
Breathing of varying tidal volumes and rates.
Deep, gasping inspiration with a pause at full inspiration followed by a brief, insufficient release of breath.
Clusters of irregular breaths that alternate with periods of apnoea. Also termed Biot's breathing.

Subject's level of exertion at or just prior to the observation being made. Intended only to record exertion only as it might effect respirations and where it would not normally be recorded as part of general clinical observation.
The respiratory expiratory phase is longer than normal/usual. Associated with obstructive airways disease such as asthma.
Details of the amount of oxygen being delivered to the subject at the time of observation. Assumed values of 21% oxygen concentration, Fi02 of 0.21 and oxygen flow rate of 0 l/min or 0 ml/min.
Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the respirations observation. For example, level of anxiety, pain, feeding in infants, tracheostomy.
Clusters of breaths separated by intervals of apnea (no breathing) or near-apnea. May also describe a normal patter nof breathing in neonates.
Inflation of the lung during expiration and deflation of the lung during inspiration.
Acts as a container for a set of archetype which represent a single date-capture screen.
The amount of oxygen being delivered to the subject at the time of observation. Assumed values of 21% O2, Fi02 of 0.21 and Oxygen flow rate of zero.
Date of last change of filter of T cannula.
Date of last change of filter of T cannula
Close fitting nasal mask for use during non-assisted ventilation.
A nasal catheter designed for high flow administration is used.
A tracheal cannula designed for high-flow administration
The flow rate mode used for oxygen delivery.
A low-flow rate mode of oxygen delivery.
A high-flow rate mode of oxygen delivery.
Style of the oxygen admin unit.
The data and time that the humidifer water was last changed.
Type of humidifer system in use.
Details of mask used to deliver oxygen.
Evidence of skin erythema or redness, related tothe oxygen mask.
Evidence of leakage from the mask.
There is evidence of mask-related erythema.
There is no evidence of mask-related erythema.
The name of the gas administered.
The name of the gas administered.
Details of device or devices used.
Leakage evident from the root of the nose.
Leakage evident from the upper right of the mask.
Leakage evident from the upper left of the mask.
Leakage evident from the lower right of the mask.
Leakage evident from the lower left of the mask.
There are no signs of leakage
Open system - reusable humidifier (water can be manually added).
Closed system - disposable humidifier (water cannot be added without replacing the humidifier container).
Is the gas self-administered by the patient?
Details of the tracheal tube used.
The intervention is unassisted oxygen deliverry.
Date and time that the oxygen administration system filter was changed.
Continuous positive airway pressure setting for non-mechanical ventilation.
A clinical activity that has been carried out for therapeutic or diagnostic purposes.
The name of the procedu re.
Detailed structure describing the procedure carried out, including preparation and details about the method and equipment/devices used.
Was the procedure ultimately unsuccessful, from a clinical perspective? True if unsuccessful.
Details about any complication arising from the procedure.
Multimedia representation of the procedure, including images.
The reason or indication for the procedure.
An unplanned event prior to or related to the procedure, which may affect its execution e.g patient self-removed cannula.
The number of failed attempts to perform the procedure.

Record information about unplanned or unexpected activities that needed to be done during the procedure. Record the name of the task and a description within this archetype, but detail should be recorded in specific linked INSTRUCTION or ACTION archetypes.
Description of additional task performed during the procedure.
Link to a detailed record of the additional task.
Narrative description about the procedure carried out.
Details about the anatomical site of procedure.
Identification of specific methods or techniques used for procedure or intervention.
Name of additional task performed during the procedure.
The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service.
The person performing the procedure (where not the information provider).
A person assisting the key intervention performer.
Descriptions of variance in the procedure performed from that requested.
Details of information required to support process and other local requirements.
Acts as a container for a set of archetype which represent a single date-capture screen.
Record the findings and interpretation of pathology tests performed on tissues and body fluids.

Identification of the pathology test performed, sometimes including specimen type. Coding with a terminology, potientially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred, where possible. May be coded with LOINC or Snomed-CT. A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests.
Rich text or other mutlimedia representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they must be semantically equivalent.
Demographic details of the laboratory with responsibility for the test. Details of secondary laboratories may also be included.
This is an initial or interim result - further updates are anticipated.
This is the final result. No further alterations are anticipated.
This is a supplementary result ehich should be appended to a previous result.
This is a correction which should completely replace any previous results.
Concise and clinically contextualised narrative interpretation of the pathology test results.
The local ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the Placer Order Identifier.
The local ID assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the (LIS) Laboratory Information System. Equivalent to the DICOM Accession Number and the Filler Order Identifier.

Details about the specimen if all individual test results are derived from the same specimen. If the specimen is sufficiently specified with a code in the Test result name, then this additional data is not required. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per 'Result group'.
The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.
The status of the pathology test result as a whole.
The test was aborted and never completed.
The diagnostic service that performs the examination e.g. biochemistry, haematology. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.
Details of the clinician or organisation requesting the laboratory test.

A group of results. Results may be grouped by specimen, or by some other name or code to describe what binds all the results together. If a name or code is used, it is provided by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT, if possible.

Specific detailed result, including both the value of the result item, and additional information that may be useful for clinical interpretation. Results include whatever specific data items pathology labs report as part of the clinical service; it is not confined to measurements. The result is identified by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT. Examples include: glucose, haemoglobin, phenotype, titre, or scatterplot image.
Details about the individual specimen to which these ‘Result group’ test results refer, where testing of multiple specimens is required.
Single word, phrase or brief description representing the 'Conclusion'. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded ‘Overall test result status’.
Description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results, or a link to the original clinical information provided in the test request.
Additional narrative about the test not captured in other fields.
May include statements about significant, unexpected or unreliable. values, or information about the source of the value where this may be relevant to the interpretation of the result.
Additional advice on the applicability of the reference range.
The date that the analysis was performed.
Identification of pathology test requested, where the test requested differs from the test actually performed.
The tst has been registered by the laboratory but a result is not yet available.
The status of the result value.
Additional structured details of pathology test methodology followed. For example, structured details about the laboratory method and data interpretation used.
The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded ‘Result status’.
Standard layout for groups of lab tests and associated entries
A group of associated lab tests.
APACHE II was designed to measure the severity of disease for adult patients admitted to intensive care units.
Risk conferred by the temperature range in °C of the patient.
Add 4 points for patient who has body temperature >= 41°
Add 3 points for patient who has body temperature >= 30° - 31,9° or >= 39° - 40,9°
Add 1 points for patient who has body temperature >= 38,5° - 38,9° or >= 38,5°- 38,9°
Add 0 points for patient who has body temperature >= 36° - 38,4°
Add 2 points for patient who has body temperature >= 32° - 33,9°
Risk conferred by the mean arterial pressure range (mmHg) of the patient.
Add 0 points for patient who has mean arterial pressure >= 70 - 109
Add 2 points for patient who has mean arterial pressure >= 110- 129 or >= 50 - 69
Add 3 points for patient who has mean arterial pressure >= 130 - 159
Add 4 points for patient who has mean arterial pressure <= 49 or >= 160
Risk conferred by the heart rate (beats/minute) range of the patient.
Add 0 points for patient who has heart rat >= 70 - 109
Add 2 points for patient who has heart rat >= 55- 69 or >= 110- 139
Add 3 points for patient who has heart rat >= 40- 54 or >= 140 - 179
Add 4 points for patient who has heart rat <= 39 or >= 180
Risk conferred by the respiratory rate (breaths/minute) range of the patient.
Add 0 points for patient who has respiratory rate >= 12 - 24
Add 1 points for patient who has respiratory rate >= 10 - 11 or >= 25 - 34
Add 2 points for patient who has respiratory rate >= 6 -9
Add 3 points for patient who has respiratory rate >= 35 - 49
Add 4 points for patient who has respiratory rate <= 5 or >= 50
Risk conferred by the Serum Na mmol/L range of the patient.
Add 0 points for patient who has Serum Na >= 130 - 149
Add 1 points for patient who has Serum Na >= 150 - 154
Add 2 points for patient who has Serum Na >= 120 - 129 or >= 155 - 159
Add 3 points for patient who has Serum Na >= 160 - 179 or >= 111 - 119
Add 4 points for patient who has Serum Na >= 180 or <= 110
Risk conferred by the Serum K in mmol/L range of the patient.
Risk conferred by the Serum HCO3 in mmol/L from venus blood of the patient.
Risk conferred by the Serum Creatinine in (mg/dL or micromol/L) range of the patient.
Risk conferred by the Hematocrit - Hct in % from venus blood of the patient.
Risk conferred by the WBS - Lkci in % from venus blood of the patient.
Risk conferred by the patient consciousness regarding glasgow Coma Scale.
Risk conferred by the age range of the patient.
Risk conferred by the acute renal failure of the patient. If patient has (answer is YES) acute renal failure, then Serum Creatinine score doubles.
Risk conferred by the chronic health status of the patient. If the patient has a history of severe organ system insufficiency or is immunocompromised.
The number in the score represents the sum value of points assigned to each clinical parameters.
Predicted death rate of the patient regarding APACHE II formula.
Add 0 points for patient who has Serum K >= 3,5 - 5,4
Add 1 points for patient who has Serum K >= 3,0 - 3,4 or K >= 5,5 - 5,9
Add 2 points for patient who has Serum K >= 2,5 - 2,9
Add 3 points for patient who has SerumK >= 6,0 - 6,9
Add 4 points for patient who has Serum K < 2,5 or K >= 7
Add 0 points for patient who has Serum HCO3 >= 22 - 31,9
Add 1 points for patient who has Serum HCO3 >= 32 - 40.9
Add 2 points for patient who has Serum HCO3 >= 18 - 21,9
Add 3 points for patient who has Serum HCO3 >= 41 - 51,9 or Serum HCO3 >= 15 - 17,9
Add 4 points for patient who has Serum HCO3 <15
Add 5 points for nonoperative or emergency postoperative patients Add 5 points for nonoperative or emergency postoperative patients
5 points for nonoperative or emergency postoperative patients
Add 2 points for elective postoperative patients
Add 0 points for patient old <= 44 years
Add 0 points for patient old >= 45 -54 years
Add 0 points for patient old >= 55 - 64 years
Add 0 points for patient old >= 65 -74 years
Add 0 points for patient old >= 75 years
Risk conferred by the Percent O2 rate range of the patient. Risk conferred by the Percent O2 rate range of the patient.
Risk conferred by the Percent O2 rate range of the patient. If FiO2 <= 0,5 use PaO2 in mmHg from arterial blood analyze
Add 0 points for patient who has PaO2 >70 or >9,3 kPa
Add 1 points for patient who has PaO2 >= 61 - 70 or >= 8,1 - 9,3 Kpa
Add 3 points for patient who has PaO2 >= 55 - 60 or >= 7,3 - 8,0 kPa
Add 4 points for patient who has PaO2 < 55 mmHg or < 7,3 kPa
Add 0 points for patient who ha A-aDO2 < 200
Add 2 points for patient who ha A-aDO2 >= 200 - 349
Add 3 points for patient who ha A-aDO2 >= 350 - 499
Add 4 points for patient who ha A-aDO2 >= 500
Add 0 points for patient who has Lkci >= 3 - 14,9
Add 1points for patient who has Lkci >= 15 - 15,9
Add 2 points for patient who has Lkci>= 120 - 129 or Lkci >= 20 - 30,9
Add 3 points for patient who has Lkci >= 1 - 1,9
Add 4 points for patient who has Lkci <1 or Lkci >= 40
Acts as a container for a set of archetype which represent a single date-capture screen.
Generic encounter or progress note composition

Merjenje telesne temperature v ustni sluznici
Merjenje telesne temperature na način, ki ni naveden
Izmerjena telesna temperatura pacienta, ki se nanaša na celotno telo pacieta
Merjenje telesne temperature, ki se lahko nanaša na celotno telo pacieta
Izmerjena telesna temperatura za celotno telo
Anatomska stran telesa, kje se je izvajala meritev

Merjenje telesne temperature v sečnem mehurju

Glede na okoliščine je pacient primerno oblečen (zavit)
Glede na okoliščine je pacient preveč oblečen (zavit)
Opis pogojev/stanja, ki lahko vplivajo na telesno temperaturo pacienta
Merjenje telesne temperature na izpostavljenem delu telesa, na koži kjer je povišana telesna temperatura

Število ne izvedenih srčnih utripov je večje kot 2 na minuto
Število ne izvedenih srčnih utripov na minuto
Ne izvedeni srčni utripi na minuto
Stran telesa na kateri je merjen srčni utrip
Razlika med utripoma izmerjenima na srčnem apex-u in periferno
Mesto na telesu kjer je bil izmerjeno pomanjkanje utripa
Pojav, pri katerem število impulzov iz preddvorov presega 100 na minuto
Manjše zvišanje frekvence pulza kot bi bilo pričakovano pri zvišani telesni temperaturi

Srčni utrip je prisoten (označi z "true", je utrip >0)
Srčni utrip je prisoten (označi z "true", je utrip >0)

Is the blood pressure reading suitable to be displayed on a graph?
A non-invasive method was used to record blood pressure.

The left ear of the subject.

The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial. pressure in the systemic circulation. Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.

The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial. pressure in the systemic circulation. Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm. 'Unsuitable for graphing' added for local Marand ZN use.

Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a stethoscope and Korotkoff sounds.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using palpation (usually of the brachial or radial arteries).
Formula used to calculate the MAP (if recorded in data).
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a blood pressure machine.
Method of measuring blood pressure internally ie involving penetration of the skin and measuring inside blood vessels.
Estimate of the average blood pressure over a 24 hour period.
Sleep status - supports interpretation of 24 hour ambulatory blood pressure records.
Subject is in the natural state of bodily rest.
A toe of the subject. Identification of the toe can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.

Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the blood pressure measurement. For example, level of anxiety or 'white coat syndrome'; pain or fever; changes in atmospheric pressure etc.
Invasive measurement via transducer access line within an artery. Location of the transducer can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.
ALi se krvni tlak lahko prikaže na grafu?
The left ear of the subject.
*Perloff D, Grim C, Flack J, Frohlich ED, Hill M, McDonald M, Morgenstern BZ. Human blood pressure determination by sphygmomanometry. Circulation 1993;88;2460-2470. (en)
*The craniocaudal tilt of the surface on which the person is lying at the time of measurement.(en)
*Record which Korotkoff sound is used for determining diastolic pressure using auscultative method.(en)
*The fourth Korotkoff sound is identified as an abrupt muffling of sounds.(en)
*The fifth Korotkoff sound is identified by absence of sounds as the cuff pressure drops below the diastolic blood pressure.(en)
The left wrist of the subject.
*A finger of the subject. Identification of the finger can be recorded in 'Specific Location' data element, if required.(en)

*Body location where blood pressure is measured. Use 'Location of measurement' to select from common sites. Use 'Specific location' to record more specific details or a site that is not in the common set or to refer to an external terminology.(en)
*Specific details about the body site where blood pressure is recorded.(en)
*Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a stethoscope and Korotkoff sounds.(en)
*Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using palpation (usually of the brachial or radial arteries).(en)
*Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a blood pressure machine.(en)
*Method of measuring blood pressure internally ie involving penetration of the skin and measuring inside blood vessels.(en)
The observed characteristics of spontaneous breathing as would commonly be recorded as part of a 'vital signs' examination.
Specific abnormal respiratory pattern. Other patterns may be entered as free text or terminology subset defined at specialisation or template level.
Deep chest breathing with or without a visible gasp.
Periods of hyperventilation alternating with periods of apnoea.
Breathing of varying tidal volumes and rates.
Deep, gasping inspiration with a pause at full inspiration followed by a brief, insufficient release of breath.
Clusters of irregular breaths that alternate with periods of apnoea. Also termed Biot's breathing.

Subject's level of exertion at or just prior to the observation being made. Intended only to record exertion only as it might effect respirations and where it would not normally be recorded as part of general clinical observation.
The respiratory expiratory phase is longer than normal/usual. Associated with obstructive airways disease such as asthma.
Details of the amount of oxygen being delivered to the subject at the time of observation. Assumed values of 21% oxygen concentration, Fi02 of 0.21 and oxygen flow rate of 0 l/min or 0 ml/min.
Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the respirations observation. For example, level of anxiety, pain, feeding in infants, tracheostomy.
Clusters of breaths separated by intervals of apnea (no breathing) or near-apnea. May also describe a normal patter nof breathing in neonates.
Inflation of the lung during expiration and deflation of the lung during inspiration.
*Breathing of varying tidal volumes and rates.(en)
*Deep, gasping inspiration with a pause at full inspiration followed by a brief, insufficient release of breath.(en)
*Clusters of irregular breaths that alternate with periods of apnoea. Also termed Biot's breathing.(en)

*Subject's level of exertion at or just prior to the observation being made. Intended only to record exertion only as it might effect respirations and where it would not normally be recorded as part of general clinical observation.(en)
Faza izdiha je podaljšana glede na normalno dolžino te faze v primerjavi s fazo vdiha. Povezano z obstruktivnimi boleznimi, npr. astmo.
Delež kisika v vdihanem zraku. Privzeta vrednost je 21%
*Comment on and record other incidental factors that may be contributing to the respirations observation. For example, level of anxiety, pain, feeding in infants, tracheostomy.(en)
*Clusters of breaths separated by intervals of apnea (no breathing) or near-apnea. May also describe a normal patter nof breathing in neonates.(en)
*Inflation of the lung during expiration and deflation of the lung during inspiration.(en)
The intervention is unassisted oxygen deliverry.
Date and time that the oxygen administration system filter was changed.
Continuous positive airway pressure setting for non-mechanical ventilation.
A clinical activity that has been carried out for therapeutic or diagnostic purposes.
The name of the procedu re.
Detailed structure describing the procedure carried out, including preparation and details about the method and equipment/devices used.
Was the procedure ultimately unsuccessful, from a clinical perspective? True if unsuccessful.
Details about any complication arising from the procedure.
Multimedia representation of the procedure, including images.
The reason or indication for the procedure.
An unplanned event prior to or related to the procedure, which may affect its execution e.g patient self-removed cannula.
The number of failed attempts to perform the procedure.

Record information about unplanned or unexpected activities that needed to be done during the procedure. Record the name of the task and a description within this archetype, but detail should be recorded in specific linked INSTRUCTION or ACTION archetypes.
Description of additional task performed during the procedure.
Link to a detailed record of the additional task.
Narrative description about the procedure carried out.
Details about the anatomical site of procedure.
Identification of specific methods or techniques used for procedure or intervention.
Name of additional task performed during the procedure.
The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.
The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.
Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service.
The person performing the procedure (where not the information provider).
A person assisting the key intervention performer.
Descriptions of variance in the procedure performed from that requested.
Details of information required to support process and other local requirements.
Datum in čas zadnje menjave filtra
Konstanti pozitivni pristisk zraka za spontano dihanje
*Detailed structure describing the procedure carried out, including preparation and details about the method and equipment/devices used.(en)
*Was the procedure ultimately unsuccessful, from a clinical perspective? True if unsuccessful.(en)
Nenačrtovan dogodek, npr. neželen dogodek, ki vpliva na aktivnost

*Record information about unplanned or unexpected activities that needed to be done during the procedure. Record the name of the task and a description within this archetype, but detail should be recorded in specific linked INSTRUCTION or ACTION archetypes.(en)
*Description of additional task performed during the procedure.(en)
Povazava na zapis o dodatni nalogi
*Identification of specific methods or techniques used for procedure.(en)
*Name of additional task performed during the procedure.(en)
*The local ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service. (en)
*Details about the healthcare provider or organisation requesting the service.(en)
*The ID assigned to the order by the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service. This is also referred to as Filler Order Identifier.(en)
*Details about the healthcare provider or organisation receiving the request for service.(en)
*The person performing the procedure (where not the information provider).(en)
*A person assisting the key intervention performer.(en)
*Descriptions of variance in the procedure performed from that requested.(en)
*Details of information required to support process and other local requirements.(en)
Date of last change of filter of T cannula.
Date of last change of filter of T cannula
Close fitting nasal mask for use during non-assisted ventilation.
A nasal catheter designed for high flow administration is used.
A tracheal cannula designed for high-flow administration
The flow rate mode used for oxygen delivery.
A low-flow rate mode of oxygen delivery.
A high-flow rate mode of oxygen delivery.
Style of the oxygen admin unit.
The data and time that the humidifer water was last changed.
Type of humidifer system in use.
Details of mask used to deliver oxygen.
Evidence of skin erythema or redness, related tothe oxygen mask.
Evidence of leakage from the mask.
There is evidence of mask-related erythema.
There is no evidence of mask-related erythema.
The name of the gas administered.
The name of the gas administered.
Details of device or devices used.
Leakage evident from the root of the nose.
Leakage evident from the upper right of the mask.
Leakage evident from the upper left of the mask.
Leakage evident from the lower right of the mask.
Leakage evident from the lower left of the mask.
There are no signs of leakage
Open system - reusable humidifier (water can be manually added).
Closed system - disposable humidifier (water cannot be added without replacing the humidifier container).
Is the gas self-administered by the patient?
Details of the tracheal tube used.
Datum in čas zadnje menjave vode v vlažilcu
Ali je prisotna rdečina na mestu, kjer se maska dotika kože?
Opis aparata, ki se ga uporablja za aspiracijo
The amount of oxygen being delivered to the subject at the time of observation. Assumed values of 21% O2, Fi02 of 0.21 and Oxygen flow rate of zero.
Količina kiska, ki jo dobil pacient v času opazovanja
Standard layout for groups of lab tests and associated entries
A group of associated lab tests.
*Standard layout for groups of lab tests and associated entries(en)
Record the findings and interpretation of pathology tests performed on tissues and body fluids.

Identification of the pathology test performed, sometimes including specimen type. Coding with a terminology, potientially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred, where possible. May be coded with LOINC or Snomed-CT. A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests.
Rich text or other mutlimedia representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they must be semantically equivalent.
Demographic details of the laboratory with responsibility for the test. Details of secondary laboratories may also be included.
This is an initial or interim result - further updates are anticipated.
This is the final result. No further alterations are anticipated.
This is a supplementary result ehich should be appended to a previous result.
This is a correction which should completely replace any previous results.
Concise and clinically contextualised narrative interpretation of the pathology test results.
The local ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the Placer Order Identifier.
The local ID assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the (LIS) Laboratory Information System. Equivalent to the DICOM Accession Number and the Filler Order Identifier.

Details about the specimen if all individual test results are derived from the same specimen. If the specimen is sufficiently specified with a code in the Test result name, then this additional data is not required. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per 'Result group'.
The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.
The status of the pathology test result as a whole.
The test was aborted and never completed.
The diagnostic service that performs the examination e.g. biochemistry, haematology. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.
Details of the clinician or organisation requesting the laboratory test.

A group of results. Results may be grouped by specimen, or by some other name or code to describe what binds all the results together. If a name or code is used, it is provided by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT, if possible.

Specific detailed result, including both the value of the result item, and additional information that may be useful for clinical interpretation. Results include whatever specific data items pathology labs report as part of the clinical service; it is not confined to measurements. The result is identified by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT. Examples include: glucose, haemoglobin, phenotype, titre, or scatterplot image.
Details about the individual specimen to which these ‘Result group’ test results refer, where testing of multiple specimens is required.
Single word, phrase or brief description representing the 'Conclusion'. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded ‘Overall test result status’.
Description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results, or a link to the original clinical information provided in the test request.
Additional narrative about the test not captured in other fields.
May include statements about significant, unexpected or unreliable. values, or information about the source of the value where this may be relevant to the interpretation of the result.
Additional advice on the applicability of the reference range.
The date that the analysis was performed.
Identification of pathology test requested, where the test requested differs from the test actually performed.
The tst has been registered by the laboratory but a result is not yet available.
The status of the result value.
Additional structured details of pathology test methodology followed. For example, structured details about the laboratory method and data interpretation used.
The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded ‘Result status’.
*Record the findings and interpretation of pathology tests performed on tissues and body fluids.(en)

*Identification of the pathology test performed, sometimes including specimen type. Coding with a terminology, potientially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred, where possible. May be coded with LOINC or Snomed-CT. A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests.(en)
*Rich text or other mutlimedia representation of the entire result as issued by the diagnostic service. Multiple formats are allowed but they must be semantically equivalent.(en)
*Demographic details of the laboratory with responsibility for the test. Details of secondary laboratories may also be included.(en)
*This is an initial or interim result - further updates are anticipated.(en)
*This is the final result. No further alterations are anticipated.(en)
*This is a supplementary result ehich should be appended to a previous result.(en)
*This is a correction which should completely replace any previous results.(en)
*Concise and clinically contextualised narrative interpretation of the pathology test results.(en)
*The local ID assigned to the order by the order requester. Equivalent to the Placer Order Identifier.(en)
*The local ID assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the (LIS) Laboratory Information System. Equivalent to the DICOM Accession Number and the Filler Order Identifier.(en)

*Details about the specimen if all individual test results are derived from the same specimen. If the specimen is sufficiently specified with a code in the Test result name, then this additional data is not required. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per 'Result group'.(en)
*The identifier given to the laboratory test result of a pathology investigation.(en)
*The status of the pathology test result as a whole.(en)
*The test was aborted and never completed.(en)
*The diagnostic service that performs the examination e.g. biochemistry, haematology. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.(en)
*Details of the clinician or organisation requesting the laboratory test.(en)

*A group of results. Results may be grouped by specimen, or by some other name or code to describe what binds all the results together. If a name or code is used, it is provided by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT, if possible.(en)

*Specific detailed result, including both the value of the result item, and additional information that may be useful for clinical interpretation. Results include whatever specific data items pathology labs report as part of the clinical service; it is not confined to measurements. The result is identified by run-time re-naming of the 'Result group' element or may be fixed in a specialised archetype or template. Coding with a terminology, potentially a pre-coordinated term including specimen type, is preferred where possible for the name. Should be coded with LOINC or SNOMED CT. Examples include: glucose, haemoglobin, phenotype, titre, or scatterplot image.(en)
*Details about the individual specimen to which these ‘Result group’ test results refer, where testing of multiple specimens is required.(en)
*Single word, phrase or brief description representing the 'Conclusion'. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.(en)
*The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded ‘Overall test result status’.(en)
*Description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results, or a link to the original clinical information provided in the test request.(en)
*Additional narrative about the test not captured in other fields.(en)
*May include statements about significant, unexpected or unreliable. values, or information about the source of the value where this may be relevant to the interpretation of the result.(en)
*Additional advice on the applicability of the reference range.(en)
*The date that the analysis was performed.(en)
*Identification of pathology test requested, where the test requested differs from the test actually performed.(en)
*The tst has been registered by the laboratory but a result is not yet available.(en)
*Additional structured details of pathology test methodology followed. For example, structured details about the laboratory method and data interpretation used.(en)
*The date and/or time that the result was issued for the recorded ‘Result status’.(en)
APACHE II was designed to measure the severity of disease for adult patients admitted to intensive care units.
Risk conferred by the temperature range in °C of the patient.
Add 4 points for patient who has body temperature >= 41°
Add 3 points for patient who has body temperature >= 30° - 31,9° or >= 39° - 40,9°
Add 1 points for patient who has body temperature >= 38,5° - 38,9° or >= 38,5°- 38,9°
Add 0 points for patient who has body temperature >= 36° - 38,4°
Add 2 points for patient who has body temperature >= 32° - 33,9°
Risk conferred by the mean arterial pressure range (mmHg) of the patient.
Add 0 points for patient who has mean arterial pressure >= 70 - 109
Add 2 points for patient who has mean arterial pressure >= 110- 129 or >= 50 - 69
Add 3 points for patient who has mean arterial pressure >= 130 - 159
Add 4 points for patient who has mean arterial pressure <= 49 or >= 160
Risk conferred by the heart rate (beats/minute) range of the patient.
Add 0 points for patient who has heart rat >= 70 - 109
Add 2 points for patient who has heart rat >= 55- 69 or >= 110- 139
Add 3 points for patient who has heart rat >= 40- 54 or >= 140 - 179
Add 4 points for patient who has heart rat <= 39 or >= 180
Risk conferred by the respiratory rate (breaths/minute) range of the patient.
Add 0 points for patient who has respiratory rate >= 12 - 24
Add 1 points for patient who has respiratory rate >= 10 - 11 or >= 25 - 34
Add 2 points for patient who has respiratory rate >= 6 -9
Add 3 points for patient who has respiratory rate >= 35 - 49
Add 4 points for patient who has respiratory rate <= 5 or >= 50
Risk conferred by the Serum Na mmol/L range of the patient.
Add 0 points for patient who has Serum Na >= 130 - 149
Add 1 points for patient who has Serum Na >= 150 - 154
Add 2 points for patient who has Serum Na >= 120 - 129 or >= 155 - 159
Add 3 points for patient who has Serum Na >= 160 - 179 or >= 111 - 119
Add 4 points for patient who has Serum Na >= 180 or <= 110
Risk conferred by the Serum K in mmol/L range of the patient.
Risk conferred by the Serum HCO3 in mmol/L from venus blood of the patient.
Risk conferred by the Serum Creatinine in (mg/dL or micromol/L) range of the patient.
Risk conferred by the Hematocrit - Hct in % from venus blood of the patient.
Risk conferred by the WBS - Lkci in % from venus blood of the patient.
Risk conferred by the patient consciousness regarding glasgow Coma Scale.
Risk conferred by the age range of the patient.
Risk conferred by the acute renal failure of the patient. If patient has (answer is YES) acute renal failure, then Serum Creatinine score doubles.
Risk conferred by the chronic health status of the patient. If the patient has a history of severe organ system insufficiency or is immunocompromised.
The number in the score represents the sum value of points assigned to each clinical parameters.
Predicted death rate of the patient regarding APACHE II formula.
Add 0 points for patient who has Serum K >= 3,5 - 5,4
Add 1 points for patient who has Serum K >= 3,0 - 3,4 or K >= 5,5 - 5,9
Add 2 points for patient who has Serum K >= 2,5 - 2,9
Add 3 points for patient who has SerumK >= 6,0 - 6,9
Add 4 points for patient who has Serum K < 2,5 or K >= 7
Add 0 points for patient who has Serum HCO3 >= 22 - 31,9
Add 1 points for patient who has Serum HCO3 >= 32 - 40.9
Add 2 points for patient who has Serum HCO3 >= 18 - 21,9
Add 3 points for patient who has Serum HCO3 >= 41 - 51,9 or Serum HCO3 >= 15 - 17,9
Add 4 points for patient who has Serum HCO3 <15
Add 5 points for nonoperative or emergency postoperative patients Add 5 points for nonoperative or emergency postoperative patients
5 points for nonoperative or emergency postoperative patients
Add 2 points for elective postoperative patients
Add 0 points for patient old <= 44 years
Add 0 points for patient old >= 45 -54 years
Add 0 points for patient old >= 55 - 64 years
Add 0 points for patient old >= 65 -74 years
Add 0 points for patient old >= 75 years
Risk conferred by the Percent O2 rate range of the patient. Risk conferred by the Percent O2 rate range of the patient.
Risk conferred by the Percent O2 rate range of the patient. If FiO2 <= 0,5 use PaO2 in mmHg from arterial blood analyze
Add 0 points for patient who has PaO2 >70 or >9,3 kPa
Add 1 points for patient who has PaO2 >= 61 - 70 or >= 8,1 - 9,3 Kpa
Add 3 points for patient who has PaO2 >= 55 - 60 or >= 7,3 - 8,0 kPa
Add 4 points for patient who has PaO2 < 55 mmHg or < 7,3 kPa
Add 0 points for patient who ha A-aDO2 < 200
Add 2 points for patient who ha A-aDO2 >= 200 - 349
Add 3 points for patient who ha A-aDO2 >= 350 - 499
Add 4 points for patient who ha A-aDO2 >= 500
Add 0 points for patient who has Lkci >= 3 - 14,9
Add 1points for patient who has Lkci >= 15 - 15,9
Add 2 points for patient who has Lkci>= 120 - 129 or Lkci >= 20 - 30,9
Add 3 points for patient who has Lkci >= 1 - 1,9
Add 4 points for patient who has Lkci <1 or Lkci >= 40

Additional contextual detail to be applied to all compositions.

The period of care to which this composition belongs. This equates to the CONTSYS concept and repesents an admisitrative or contractual spell of care, involving a specific instiution or care provider.
The identifier of the departmental period of care to which this Composition belongs.
Portlet ID from which stores the information where was the composition saved.

ID časa zdravljenja, ki mu pripada ta composition. This equates to the CONTSYS concept and repesents an admisitrative or contractual spell of care, involving a specific instiution or care provider.(en)
ID časa zdravljenja na oddelku, ki mu pripada ta composition.
ID portleta v katerem so shranjene informacije o shranjenom composition-u.
